author: Tevo
title: PCDiscord - Discord Partnership
description: **Communication** is the most difficult challenge for Catalyst. Discord is an **engagement epicenter** and needs help to reach its full potential.

assessments.note: The benefits from the discord partnership could improve some aspects of the discord experience for the Catalyst community, but most of them are not functional, but rather cosmetic - vanity URL, fancy partner server badge, animated server icon etc. Some additional information regarding which of the perks they view as being the ones that make a difference would give some beneficial insight.
The problem and the solution are reasonable, the Partner program with Discord would bring relevant improvements to the Discord channel and these improvements would bring value to the onboarding.

I believe that the perks and benefits are good, but they are not essential to increase the engagement with participants in the community. I'm not sure if there are other benefits in being partner with Discord that were not mentioned in the text, but I see that the 2 servers bots are the most usable perks among them. The reward for active user is also a good incentive, but it might be difficult to make fair decisions by  2 people only, since there is a lot going on in the Discord server. Anyway, the budget is quite low and this might be a good experiment.
Seems a reasonable plan from current discord moderators for a small sum of funds

The proposal is a valid attempt at addressing the challenge with a focus on improved electronic communication. The problem is well defined and there appears to be a high need for improved interface for the community.

The team has not provided links to their prior experience, though they are indeed very active members on the Catalyst discord server. It is hard to assess their knowledge based only on their admin status and activity on discord. Otherwise, the proposal is easy to understand and seems reasonably easy to implement.

The two proposers are moderators on the Discord Catalyst server and are participatory members of the community, having involvement in other proposals for improvements to Catalyst, such as Swarm Sessions and Landing Page development.

The problem is that there is no clear description of the plan to generate the necessary engagement to reach 7000 members and that will be an important factor. The risks of this not being reached in the following 2 Funds were not considered, which would cause the proposal to escape the deadline established in the challenge.

As far as I could understand, this Discord plan can also be achieved with a subscription of $ 150 per month, wouldn't it be more practical to request funding to pay for that subscription until we reach the 7000 member mark on the server?

The proposal is completely feasible based on the proposer's experience. Although, I don't see these improvements in the Discord server being responsible for increasing the number of community members significantly, since they would affect them only after they have already signed up, so I'm not sure how this would impact the growth rate of new members, so if the current growth projection does not show that 7000 will already be there after 6 months, the only reason to increase the number of members would be the possibility to receive rewards for participation, but I'm not sure how effective this would be to solve the problem. But I believe it is worth trying since the required budget is low.

The plan is not really all that clear on how the rewards scheme will be decided. Is this just on the proposers opinion? There is no plan on how they intend to reach the goal of 7000 users. How do unexpected rewards drive meaningful participation?

The experience of the team is strong for the proposal being submitted and this suggests that a successful implementation will follow. The plan seems straightforward and is not excessive in terms of promising to deliver an achievable outcome that will be subject to community interaction and comment.

The link to the discord partnership program they provided states that to be eligible, the server would need 500 members, not 7000 and Catalyst already has more than 1900. Is there another link with those numbers?
The metrics provided are easily verifiable, discord is open to anyone so it would also be easy to monitor their progress.

Despite the simplicity in the purpose of the proposal, there is no reasonable plan for how the server will reach 7000 members in the set time. Objective KPIs have been established. There are no details on budget allocation. I believe that the information described is insufficient to audit the proposal efficiently.

The goals after 3, 6 and 12 months are clear. It should be good to have some way to measure members activity and their contributions, so there is a basis to reward them and to justify the reward instead of only a subjective decision made by an admin. It should also mention the time span in which the rewards would be distributed, for example, would it take 12 months? Or less? Rewards should be publicly disclosed to improve accountability.

Its not clear the mechanisms for how this will actually drive meaningful participation and how the rewards will be handed out. It would be good to have detail here. Saying that it is a modest request.

The information provided was easy to follow although I feel there is some leeway required to allow for further iterations that are likely to develop with application. The proposal overall represents a real application of the community in action developing an improved user interface that hopefully improves onboarding for newcomers to the community.

solution: **PCDiscord** creates value, increases collaboration, provides insights to measure KPIs, and is an **engagement epicenter. To reach full potential**
experience: Discord moderator for 5 years in various channels.
